Polygamy presents enormous difficulties when you consider that civil marriage is first and foremost a legal contract. (Which it was, by the way, long before it was a religious sacrament. Religion frowned on the institution before throwing in the towel and co-opting it.) An arrangement between two parties becomes exponentially more complex when you add even one, much less two or more, and the result would inevitably be a logistical nightmare.
 
 Are they all supposed to be considered equally married to each other? If so what happens in the case of divorce? Can one person divorce only one (or a few) of the others, yet remain married to the remainder? 
 
 Do we draw a line at a specific number of participants? Or could, say, the population of the state of New Jersey theoretically all marry each other? 
 
 Also, the type of relationship typified by real-world polygamy--at least the ones taken to court in the US--tend to be religion or cult-based patriarchal set-ups with one man and many wives (some of whom may also be blood-related), more resembling harems than the sexually-faithful, mutually devoted, 50/50 relationships the vast majority of people envisage as being core to the whole notion of modern marriage.
 
 The problems associated with legalized polygamy, imho, vastly outnumber those resulting from other non-traditional marital forms, which is why I don't think any same-sex slippery slope is going to open any floodgates for it, scare-mongering fundies notwithstanding.

 Polygamy and incest both carry the same fear whether true or not and that is the potential for abuse of minors. That does not strictly entail physical abuse. When parents and siblings take relationships (as whatever age of child) beyond what is determined normal or healthy there exists a question of whether coercion or manipulation was a factor. Which ultimately leads to capacity to consent. That doesn't mean it is always present nor that there will be instances where everything would work out just fine. As a society we make judgment calls about situations and government tends to be reactive while leaning towards the safety. The reason some turns on freeways drop to 10 mph, because in a worst case scenario that will prevent an accident. So we balance the potential for harm vs the benefits and infringement on individual freedom.
 
 What Guano is doing is defending a small situation within incest where siblings have grown up healthy and normal and as adults find each other as most compatible. Take kids out of this equation and it seems there really is not much to say against. The problem is this isn't the dominate form of incest, but it is the only defensible form. 
 
 What he also won't do is explain why his argument is all or none. Let each stand up for itself and be deemed good or bad for what it is by itself. The fact that all have very little in common is lost on him because he needs to keep them together in order to continue the argument, just as he needs to let people think he means every instance of incest.
 
 Notice he doesn't defend or offer why polygamy or incest should be legal based solely on polygamy or incest. His primary reason is based on an acceptance of gay marriage. If we legalize pot does that mean PCP should also be legal. No because while both are drugs one has more potential to cause harm than the other, even though both could
 
 We govern ourselves (in theory at least) and when enough of the people agree on what will be legal and what will not then they have the opportunity to bring that to fruition. Nothing is preventing polygamists (who are trying) or incestuous people from doing what gays have done to be able to marry.
